pyLib.math package¶

Submodules¶

pyLib.math.extnp module¶

pyLib.math.extnp.blockIndex(i, j, rows, cols, order='C')[source]¶

For a matrix block, we return the index of row and columns.

For a matrix we choose a block using the upper left corner positioned at (i, j) and size (row, col). Each element of the block has row and col index, they are returned in two arrays. The order controls we use row or column major order

For example, blockIndex(1, 3, 2, 3, ‘C’) returns (array([1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2]), array([3, 4, 5, 3, 4, 5])) :param i: int, the row of the upper left corner :param j: int, the column of the upper left corner :param rows: int, number of rows of the block :param cols: int, number of columns of the block :param order, char, (‘C’/’F’) if we return row or column major

pyLib.math.gradient module¶

gradient.py

Tools for calculating gradients based solely on data. Monte-Carlo like approach and only return the norm.

pyLib.math.gradient.finiteDiff(fun, x, args=(), kwargs={}, f0=None, step=1e-06, method='f')[source]¶

Use finite differentiation to estimate gradient or Jacobian at a point x

f: the function to be differentiated, must be be like y = f(x, args) x: the point to be evaluated, np.ndarray (n,) args(,): additional arguments for f

pyLib.math.gradient.gradNorm(x, y, knn=5, dsrate=1)[source]¶

Given dataset x-y, try to estimate the gradients. knn is # neighbors for gradient estimation dsrate is downsampling rate, used in eval not build

pyLib.math.gradient.verboseGradNorm(x, y, knn=5, dsrate=1)[source]¶

Get complete information for gradient of the field. Aiming at detecting discontinuity.

pyLib.math.stat module¶

Functions associated with statistics

pyLib.math.stat.checkstd(std, tol=0.001)[source]¶

Assume it is a 1 by n vector

pyLib.math.stat.destdify(x, mean, std)[source]¶

Recover to original x

pyLib.math.stat.getMeanStd(data, cols=None, axis=0)[source]¶

Standardize a data, taken into consideration that certain data has to be scaled in the same metric.

Parameters:
  • data – ndarray, the data to be standardized
  • cols – a list or single one ndarray, the columns that have to be scaled at the same time.
Returns:

mean, the mean of the dataset
Returns:

std, the standard deviation of the dataset
pyLib.math.stat.getPCA(x, n_components=3, scale=True)[source]¶

A quick shortcut for performing PCA.

x : ndarray, the data to be processed n_components : int, number of components scale : bool, if we apply standard scaler on x

x_proj : ndarray, projected data

pyLib.math.stat.getStandardData(data, cols=None, return_meanstd=False, axis=0)[source]¶

Standardize the dataset, return that value.

See getMeanStd for detailed documentation.
